facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1950, of the former Travancore Cochin High Court in A. S. No. 288 of 1120 T.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 165 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1950, of the former Travancore Cochin High Court in A. S. No. 288 of 1120 T  arising out of the judgment and order dated the 3rd Thulum 1120 of the 2nd Judge, District Court, Quilon in C.M.P. No. 2391 dated 15-8-1103 in I.P. 3/1100.

facts.text: Usufructuary mortgage Ex. I for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924, executed by heirs of Koya Kunju.

anchor.surface_text: annulling the usufructuary mortgage  Ex. I  for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924, executed by a number of persons who may number be companyveniently described as the insolvents.

facts.text: Koya Kunju died in or about the year 1921 leaving surviving his widow, two sons and two daughters.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the arguments in this appeal it is necessary to state the following facts. Koya Kunju was a flourishing merchant at Quilon carrying on trade in piece goods, yarn, provisions etc. He died in or about the year 1921 leaving him surviving his widow, two sons and two daughters, who jointly carried on the ancestral business through the eldest son under a power of attorney.

facts.text: Heirs of Koya Kunju jointly carried on the ancestral business through the eldest son under a power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: He died in or about the year 1921 leaving him surviving his widow, two sons and two daughters, who jointly carried on the ancestral business through the eldest son under a power of attorney. They added to the family business a tile factory and an oil mill.

facts.text: In June-July 1924 the sons approached the appellants father, a money-lender at Mankompu, about 50-60 miles from Quilon.

anchor.surface_text: In June-July 1924 the sons approached the appellants father, who was a flourishing money-lender living about fifty to sixty miles away from Quilon at a place called Mankompu.

facts.text: Appellant's father agreed to advance Rs. 75,000 on usufructuary mortgage of immovable properties in and near Quilon.

anchor.surface_text: He agreed to advance the sum of Rs. 75,000 on the usufructuary mortgage of certain immovable properties in and near Quilon belonging to the family, for the purpose of carrying on their trade and business after his two sons had made certain enquiries at Quilon about the status and means of the borrowers and whether the transaction would be worth their while.

facts.text: Mortgage bond and lease deed both dated August 18, 1924, executed and registered by heirs of Koya Kunju.

anchor.surface_text: After a draft had been made at the instance of the creditor, the mortgage bond and a lease deed granting a lease of the mortgaged properties to the mortgagors themselves bearing the same date, namely, August 18, 1924, were executed and registered by the heirs aforesaid.said of Koya Kunju.

facts.text: Purpose of loan stated as family necessity, carrying on trade etc.

anchor.surface_text: The purpose of the loan is stated in the document to be the family necessity, namely, carrying on trade etc.

facts.text: Mortgaged properties unencumbered at date of transaction.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the mortgaged properties were unencumbered at the date of the transaction, but soon after a hypothecation deed in favour of a third party named Kadir Moideen Rowther was executed on August 30, 1924, for the sum of Rs. 78,859-15-0, hypothecating the equity of redemption in respect of the properties mortgaged to the appellant and certain other properties.

facts.text: Hypothecation deed dated August 30, 1924, for Rs. 78,859-15-0 to Kadir Moideen Rowther.

anchor.surface_text: but soon after a hypothecation deed in favour of a third party named Kadir Moideen Rowther was executed on August 30, 1924, for the sum of Rs. 78,859-15-0, hypothecating the equity of redemption in respect of the properties mortgaged to the appellant and certain other properties.

facts.text: Insolvency application by S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther on September 15, 1924, against five heirs of Koya Kunju.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1924, one of the business creditors of the family of the mortgagors,S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther, made an application in the District Court of Quilon for adjudicating them as insolvents.

facts.text: District Judge adjudged counter-petitioners insolvents on August 29, 1927.

anchor.surface_text: All those proceedings appear to have been companysolidated and the District Judge by his orders dated August 29, 1927, adjudged the companynter petitioners insolvents.

facts.text: Official Receiver appointed interim receiver on October 19, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: By his orders dated October 19, 1924, the District Judge appointed the Official Receiver as the interim receiver in respect of the insolvents properties to take immediate possession thereof.

facts.text: Official Receiver applied on March 28, 1928, to annul transfers including usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: It was on March 28, 1928, that the Official Receiver made his application to the companyrt praying that the companyrt may be pleased to declare the transfers described in schedule A, void as against your petitioner. Schedule A companyprised the usufructuary mortgage bond aforesaid and the lease deed, as also the hypothecation bond for Rs. 78,859-15-0.

facts.text: District Judge allowed Official Receiver's application on October 19, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: the annulment proceedings companymenced in 1928 and were determined by the Court of first instance by its orders dated October 19, 1944,

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal on October 3, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the mortgagee, the learned Judges of the High Court dis- agreed with the trial Judge ... In the result the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal.

facts.text: District Judge found only Rs. 20,000 paid out of Rs. 75,000.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held on the merits that Ex. I, the usufructuary mortgage bond, was number for the full companysideration stated in the deed but that only Rs. 20,000 had been paid to the mortgagors

facts.text: High Court found entire Rs. 75,000 consideration paid.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has found that the entire companysideration passed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transaction made in good faith and for valuable consideration, not annulled.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the companyrts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents.

facts.text: Mortgagee instituted suit for arrears of rent and possession, decreed.

anchor.surface_text: The rent having fallen in arrears over two years, the mortgagee instituted a suit against the mortgagors, impleading the Official Receiver also for recovery of arrears of rent with interest, as also for recovery of possession of the mortgaged property and the suit appears to have been decreed for the reliefs prayed for.

facts.text: First counter-petitioner admitted debts including under mortgage bond amounted to two and a half lakhs, assets worth not less than seven lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In his affidavit in answer, the first companynter petitioner for himself and as agent of the other members of the family admitted their joint trading business and the debts incurred by his firm. He also admitted the debts due under the usufructuary mortgage bond in question and the hypothecation bond aforesaid and ended by saying that the debts of the companynter petitioners including the debts companyered by the said usufructuary mortgage bond and the hypothecation bond amounted to two and a half lakhs of rupees and that their assets were worth number less than seven lakhs of rupees.

facts.text: Mortgagee's two sons made enquiries at Quilon about borrowers' status.

anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of carrying on their trade and business after his two sons had made certain enquiries at Quilon about the status and means of the borrowers and whether the transaction would be worth their while.

facts.text: Interim receiver reported on February 11, 1925, that mortgaged properties yield estimated Rs. 1,600 per year.

anchor.surface_text: The interim receiver, Sri V. N. Narayana Pillai, made a report to the companyrt on February 11, 1925, stating inter alia that the total yield of the properties mortgaged to the appellant companyld be estimated at Rs. 1,600 per year

facts.text: Rs. 55,000 paid in cash on August 20, 1924, remaining Rs. 20,000 in instalments September 1-9, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: out of the Rs. 75,000 agreed to be advanced on the mortgage when some of the mortgagors went with the registered document to the mortgagees place, Rs. 55,000 was paid in cash to them on the basis of the receipt  Ex. LIV  dated August 20, 1924. The remaining Rs. 20,000, according to the evidence, was paid later.

In this judgment we shall use the dates with reference to the Gregorian Calendar equivalent to the dates maintained under the Malayalam Calendar . In order to appreciate the arguments in this appeal it is necessary to state the following facts.

issues.text: Whether the otti and lease deeds impeached by the Receiver were executed in good faith and for valuable consideration

anchor.surface_text: A number of issues were raised on July 24, 1929, the most important of them being the first issue to the following effect Whether the otti and lease deeds impeached by the Receiver were executed in good faith and for valuable consideration Other issues related to the formal issues in bar of the proceedings

issues.text: whether it has been proved that the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18,1924, was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration

anchor.surface_text: Having disposed of the preliminary questions raised on behalf of the parties, we have now to determine the main question in controversy, namely, whether it has been proved that the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18,1924, was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration.

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in applying the test [of due care and attention] in determining the question of bona fides

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it is necessary to determine whether the High Court was right in applying the test aforesaid in determining the question of bona fides. We have to find which of the two tests, the one laid down in the General Clauses Act of Travancore-Cochin or the other laid down in the Indian Act, is more appropriate to proceedings in insolvency.

arguments.claim: The matter is res judicata between the parties due to the adjudication order, based on Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta; transferee can only appeal the adjudication order.

arguments.claim: Transaction not in good faith as entered without due care and attention.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event the transaction did not represent a bona fide transfer.

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrong test; good faith means honesty, not due care; mortgagee honest, no knowledge of insolvency intent.

arguments.claim: Mortgagee failed to prove due care and attention in entering transaction.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court came to the conclusion that the mortgagee has not proved that the mortgage transaction was entered into with due care and attention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Due care definition from General Clauses Act repugnant in insolvency context; honesty test applies; mortgagee honest.

arguments.claim: Good faith requires due care and attention per Travancore General Clauses Act s.2 cl.6.

anchor.surface_text: the General Clauses Act II of 1072 1897 , in cl. 6 of s. 2 provides that Nothing is said to be done or believed in good faith which is done or believed without due care and attention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Repugnant in insolvency subject/context; honesty test (Indian General Clauses Act) more appropriate for protecting honest creditors.

arguments.claim: Receiver discharged burden; mortgage without full consideration.

anchor.surface_text: It has been strenuously argued on behalf of the respondent that the mortgage bond in question was without consideration.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: yclusion that the mortgagee has number proved that the mortgage transaction was entered into with due care and attention. The United State of Travanco

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence shows full payment; late denial by mortgagors unbelievable; receiver made no proper inquiry.

arguments.claim: Transaction within third exception to s.35: good faith and valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The main question for determination in this appeal on behalf of the transferee is whether the transaction in his favour is within the third exception to s. 35 aforesaid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Full consideration proved; good faith (honesty) established; no privity to fraud.

arguments.claim: Otti and lease deeds executed in good faith and for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the otti and lease deeds impeached by the Receiver were executed in good faith and for valuable consideration

arguments.court_reasoning: Burden on receiver not discharged; evidence supports.

arguments.claim: s.35 applies: transfer void against receiver unless exceptions; receiver proves no good faith/consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Any transfer of property not being [exceptions], if transferor adjudged insolvent within two years, void against receiver; third exception protects transferee in good faith for valuable consideration; burden on receiver to prove otherwise.

arguments.claim: Joint trial of mortgage and hypothecation prejudiced appellant's case.

anchor.surface_text: It had been argued on behalf of the appellant that his case had been seriously prejudiced by the joint trial

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to pronounce in view of findings on main issues.

arguments.claim: Transaction beyond two years from adjudication; not within s.35.

anchor.surface_text: the mortgage bond in question had been executed and registered and given effect to beyond two years from the date of adjudication

arguments.claim: Good faith in insolvency means honesty, not due care; local General Clauses definition inapplicable.
Mortgagee made sufficient enquiries; no notice of insolvency.

anchor.surface_text: Before advancing this large sum of money the creditor had deputed his two advocate sons... to make enquiries into the antecedents...

arguments.court_reasoning: Enquiries from respectable persons; borrowers reputed solvent; no duty to further probe absent suspicion.

holdings.text: The order of adjudication does not make the matter res judicata in annulment proceedings under s.35 as there was no finding on the transferee's good faith or valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, there is no finding that the transferee was privy to such acts. It was not necessary to find at that stage, and it has not in terms been found, that the transaction impugned in this case was not bona fide so far as the transferee is concerned or without consideration matters which directly arise for determination in the annulment proceedings leading up to this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adjudication found acts of insolvency by transferor but no finding on transferee's privity, good faith, or consideration; even assuming Privy Council precedent applies, issue remains open.

holdings.text: The initial burden of proof lies on the Official Receiver to show that the transaction was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: A number of points were raised on behalf of the appellant and at the threshold of the arguments it was contended, and in our opinion rightly, that the courts below had erred in throwing the burden on the transferee of proving affirmatively that the transaction impeached, namely, the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18, 1924, was supported by good faith and valuable consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled by Privy Council in Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow, Official Receiver v. Chettyar Firm, Pope v. Official Assignee; onus on party seeking to set aside transaction.

holdings.text: The entire consideration of Rs.75,000 passed to the mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has found that the entire consideration passed. If this finding is correct, then the fact that such a large amount had been paid by the mortgagee would take him a long way to success in proving the bona fides of the transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluminous evidence of receipts, accounts, third-party payments, admissions; receiver failed to disprove despite burden; confirms High Court finding even if burden reversed.

holdings.text: The transaction was made in good faith and for valuable consideration, falling within the third exception to s.35; not void against receiver.

anchor.surface_text: From what has been said above there cannot be the least doubt that if the burden lay on the Receiver to prove that the transaction in question was without consideration, he has hopelessly failed to discharge that burden.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receiver failed burden on consideration and good faith; full payment proved; mortgagee honest stranger with enquiries; no privity to fraud.

holdings.text: In insolvency proceedings, good faith means honesty (done honestly, even if negligent), not requiring due care and attention; Travancore General Clauses Act definition repugnant in this context.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Insolvency law protects honest creditors; due care test repugnant to subject/context per saving clause; prefers Indian General Clauses Act honesty test for policy of trade/commerce.

holdings.text: The mortgagee acted in good faith: honest, no knowledge of insolvency intent, sufficient enquiries made.

anchor.surface_text: His evidence, as also of his two sons who helped him in entering into this transaction, has impressed us as truthful and straightforward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Complete stranger, deputed sons for enquiries from respectable sources; borrowers reputed solvent; no suspicion of crash; no duty to probe further absent red flags.

holdings.text: The usufructuary mortgage and lease back transaction is binding on the insolvents' estate; annulment orders set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the courts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: within s.35 third exception; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, there is no finding that the transferee was privy to such acts. It was not necessary to find at that stage, and it has not in terms been found, that the transaction impugned in this case was not bona fide so far as the transferee is concerned or without consideration matters which directly arise for determination in the annulment proceedings leading up to this appeal.

In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the courts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents. It f

anchor.surface_text: A number of points were raised on behalf of the appellant and at the threshold of the arguments it was contended, and in our opinion rightly, that the courts below had erred in throwing the burden on the transferee of proving affirmatively that the transaction impeached, namely, the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18, 1924, was supported by good faith and valuable consideration.

In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the courts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents. It f
hat to be so in the present case, the crucial question still remains to be answered. Unless it is found that the transferee was wanting in bona fides
